metadata.title: CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers for magnetic resonance imaging guided photothermal/photodynamic therapy of ovarian cancer through necroptosis

sections.heading: Nanoscale
sections.text:
PAPER
Cite this: Nanoscale, 2019, 11, 12983
Received 11th April 2019, Accepted 19th June 2019
DOI: 10.1039/c9nr03114f

CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers for magnetic resonance imaging guided photothermal/photodynamic therapy of ovarian cancer through necroptosis
Wancheng Chen,†a Xuefei Wang,†b Bingxia Zhao,†a Rongjun Zhang,a Zhen Xie,c,d Yi He,e Ali Chen,f Xiaofang Xie,g Kaitai Yao,*a Mei Zhong*b and Miaomiao Yuan *c,a
With a high incidence and high mortality rate, ovarian cancer presents a challenge for clinical practice. It
is thus extremely urgent to investigate new diagnosis and therapy methods for the treatment of ovarian
cancer. Ternary copper-based chalcogenide nanomaterials are attractive owing to their near infrared
(NIR) response for cancer theranostic fields. However, improving the theranostic efficiency of these nano-
materials is challenging. Herein, CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers were easily synthesized and under NIR irradiation exhibited a relatively high photothermal conversion efficiency of 67.5% and a simultaneous
reactive oxygen species (ROS) generation effect. Owing to these outstanding photothermal/photo-
dynamic effects, excellent tumor ablation results could be achieved by the combined use of CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers and 808 nm NIR laser treatments. The main anticancer mechanism of CuS–MnS2 nanoflowers + NIR was likely necroptosis. In addition, the nano-flowers showed remarkable contrast enhance-
ment according to magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). These CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers could thus serve as a promising multifunctional nanotheranostic agent for MRI and as a photothermal/photodynamic
cancer therapy agent through necroptosis.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Cancer is presently the leading cause of death worldwide and a major public health problem.1 Ovarian cancer accounts for 2.5% of all malignancies in women. Most are diagnosed at a late stage, leading to a low survival rate and 5% of cancer deaths in women. In the United States each year, an estimated 22 240 new cases are diagnosed and 14 070 patients die of ovarian cancer.2 Despite great efforts, ovarian cancer remains a major threat owing to the high incidence and high mortality, and it cannot be completely cured by existing cancer therapies.
Considering the limitations of current diagnosis and therapy methods, it is crucial to investigate new strategies to offer new, improved diagnosis and therapy methods of ovarian cancer.
In the past decade, many studies have reported that nearinfrared (NIR) laser responsive nanomaterials can be used clinically as a theranostic platform for efficient diagnosis and therapy of cancer,3–6 including photothermal therapy (PTT), photodynamic therapy (PDT) and imaging. These approaches allow simultaneous monitoring and killing of tumors with high specificity and therapeutic efficiency without causing systemic effects,7–10 including noble metal Au nanostructures,11,12 carbon-based materials,13,14 and semiconductor compounds.15,16 Among them, copper chalcogenide, a broadly applied semiconductor nanoparticle, is a promising alternative because of its low cost and high stability.17–19
Owing to the relative abundance of the component elements, intrinsic NIR-band absorption and low cytotoxicity, CuS nanomaterials have been fabricated in a variety of forms for photothermal ablations, including nanoparticles,16 flower-like superstructures,19 nanorods,20 and nanocomposites.21 Although CuS nanomaterials have shown effective PTT effects for cancer treatment, some challenges remain, such as a traditional single therapeutic pattern to effectively eradicate tumors at a safe dosage. As a result, many efforts have been devoted to combine PTT and PDT in cancer therapies. For example, Cao†These authors contributed equally to this work.

et al. developed MnO2 nanosheets with a Cu2−xS coating (MnO2/Cu2−xS) loaded with a siRNA targeting heat shock protein (HSP) 70, which exhibited superior PTT/PDT efficiency.22 However, the complex synthesis process involved in the fabrication of this theranostic platform is a major limitation. Therefore, theranostic agents need to be developed. Recently, Hou et al.23 reported that PVP–Cu–Sb–S could convert the NIR laser into heat and simultaneously induced photodynamic activity. Alternatively, ternary copper-based chalcogenide nanomaterials introduced with another element, such as Bi and In, demonstrated an ability to inherit the properties from their parent binary materials.24,25 CuS nanomaterials have remarkable photoacoustic imaging but each imaging modality has its own specific drawback. Therefore, developing multimodal imaging might largely overcome the drawbacks associated with monomodal imaging.26 MRI, a facile, non-invasive and powerful nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR)-based imaging modality, has been widely applied clinically for disease diagnosis as it produces three-dimensional (3D) tomographical information with high temporal-spatial resolution of whole tissue samples.27 As reported, manganese (Mn) exhibits a MRI response.28 As a result, Cu–Mn–S nanomaterials may be an efficient agent for MRI, PPT, and simultaneous PDT.
In the present, we demonstrate the synthesis of CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers using a hydrothermal process and subsequent calcination treatment. The CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers were successfully applied for MRI-guided PPT/PDT therapy of ovarian cancer through necroptosis.

sections.heading: Results and discussion
sections.text:
Preparation and characterization of the CuS–MnS2 nanoflowers
CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers were obtained via two-steps, a hydrothermal process and subsequent calcination treatment. This synthesis method was low cost and simple, and thus feasible for large-scale production. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of the synthesized products (shown in Fig. 1a) corresponded to CuS (JCPDS#1-1281) and MnS2 (JCPDS#72-601), indicating that the product is a CuS–MnS2 complex. The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) image (Fig. 1b) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) image (Fig. 1c) illustrate that the prepared CuS–MnS2 exhibited a flower-like structure with an average diameter of approximately 400 nm. The element mapping of the CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers (Fig. 1d) indicated that the composition included S, Cu, and some Mn, in agreement with the XRD results.

sections.heading: Evaluation of the properties of the CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers
sections.text:
To evaluate the physical properties of the CuS–MnS2 nanoflowers, the UV–vis–NIR absorbance spectrum, photothermal ability, photostability, and photodynamic properties were investigated. Particle solutions with different concentrations were irradiated continuously with an 808 nm laser (1 W cm−2)
for 600 s, and their temperatures were recorded with an infrared thermal imaging camera. Fig. 2a and b clearly demonstrates the strong dependence of the photothermal conversion on CuS–MnS2 nano-flower concentration; the temperature increments (ΔT ) can be finely tuned between 0.7 and 27.2 °C by simply changing their concentration. Additionally, we also investigated the temperature changes of a 1 mg mL−1 CuS– MnS2 nano-flowers solution under radiation power varying from 0.4 to 2 W cm−2 (Fig. 2c). With increasing radiation power, ΔT was finely tuned between 7.6 °C and 36.9 °C. The results indicate that the photothermal performance of the CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers had a strong dependence to both irradiation energy and suspension concentration.
The UV–vis–NIR absorbance spectrum of the CuS–MnS2 nano-flower aqueous dispersion with a concentration of 1 mg mL−1 showed a strong absorbance in the NIR region around 800 nm with a black color (Fig. 2d). To further assess the stability of the photothermal conversion, the temperature change of an aqueous dispersion with 1 mg mL−1 CuS–MnS2 nanoflowers was monitored for four continuous heating–cooling cycles (laser on/off ). The results showed that the CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers maintained the same temperature evolution profile during each irradiation cycle, implying that the CuS– MnS2 nano-flowers have excellent photothermal stability (Fig. 2e). The light-to-heat conversion efficiency (η) of the CuS– MnS2 nano-flowers, as shown in Fig. 2f, was estimated to be ∼67.5%, which is superior to that of commercial gold nanorods (21%).29 All of these results indicate that the CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers have the potential to be a photothermal agent.
Furthermore, a NIR responsive ROS generation effect was also observed except for the photothermal effect, which has never been reported for Cu–Mn–S nanomaterials to date. The photodynamic property of the as-designed nanoparticles was

As shown in Fig. 2g, a fluorescent signal enhancement could be observed in the CuS–MnS2 nano-flower + NIR group. In contrast, only weak fluorescence was detected in the control group, phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) + NIR group, and the CuS–MnS2 nano-flower group, indicating that the generation of ROS was
induced by the combination of CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers and NIR. The above-demonstrated multifunctionality of the CuS– MnS2 nano-flowers makes them a very promising PDT reagent.
In addition to the PTT/PDT effects, it is expected that the CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers also have the potential to be a contrast agent for MRI. To prove this hypothesis, an in vitro study on the detection of MRI signals in the presence of CuS–MnS2 nano-flower solutions with different concentrations was performed with a clinically-used 3.0 T MRI instrument. With the increase in CuS–MnS2 nano-flower concentration, the MRI T1 signal intensity of the CuS–MnS2 nano-flower solution was enhanced, nearly linearly (Fig. 2h). This outstanding result in vitro indicated that these CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers have the potential for MRI in vivo.
Cellular evaluation of the CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers in vitro
Considering the desirable performance of the in vitro study, an in vitro assessment of CuS–MnS2 nano-flower biocompatibility, a necessary factor for application, was also performed. In this experiment, human ovarian carcinoma A2780 cells, human hepatocyte LO2 cells and MIHA cells, human non-small cell lung cancer H460 cells, and human lung adenocarcinoma A549 cells, using a CCK8 assay were employed to evaluate the cytotoxicity of the CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers. As shown in Fig. 3a, the cell viability had a slight decrease in two tumor cell lines (A2780 and H460). Surprisingly, in two normal liver cells (LO2 and MIHA), even at concentrations up to 1 mg ml−1, the relative activity of the cells is still as high as 95%. All of these indicated that the CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers with a good biocompatibility.

These results indicated that the CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers had the capability to generate efficient ROS to achieve the PDT effect. To examine the photo-ablation capability of the CuS– MnS2 nano-flowers in vitro, A2780 cells were chosen and irradiated under 808 nm laser, followed by LIVE/DEAD™ staining. As shown in Fig. 3c, the number of dead cells (red) increased with increasing CuS–MnS2 nano-flower concentration. These results demonstrate that the PDT and PTT effects can be induced simultaneously by the CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers to achieve a combined phototherapy effect.
In vivo evaluation of the CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers
Subsequently, the therapeutic effects of the CuS–MnS2 nanoflowers in vivo were further investigated. As shown in Fig. 4a, the tumor temperature of NOD-PrkdcscidIL2rgtm1/Bcgen (NDG) mice bearing A2780 tumors that were exposed to CuS– MnS2 nano-flowers + NIR increased and reached ∼55 °C quickly. This temperature is much greater than that (40 °C) experienced by mice administered PBS + NIR. The corresponding temperature change versus exposure time is quantitatively shown in Fig. 4b. In addition, the histological analysis of the tumor sites of each group 1 day after different treatments was also performed using hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining (Fig. 4c), with obvious tumor damage of intercellular fragmentation was observed in the CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers + NIR laser group. These results reveal that the CuS–MnS2 nanoflowers might be a promising treatment for solid tumors with high efficiency. Such outstanding anti-tumor therapeutic efficiency displayed by the CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers might
benefit from local hyperthermia by the PTT effect and the enhanced ROS reactivity for tumor necrosis. Moreover, to further demonstrate the enhancement of MRI, a CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers solution (5 mg kg−1) was intratumorally injected, and then MRI images of the tumor were obtained. Fig. 4d display that CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers can significantly enhanced T1-weighted signal after intratumorally administered, and these results highlight the potential of CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers for MRI.

sections.heading: Anticancer mechanisms of CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers + NIR
sections.text:
Apoptosis and necroptosis are two distinct main cell death mechanisms that may be activated in cells.30 To identify the anticancer mechanisms of CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers + NIR, we first quantified apoptosis-associated proteins using western blot. The expression of apoptosis-associated proteins, including cleaved caspase3 and the Bcl2/Bax2 ratio, were calculated31 (Fig. 5a). Compared with the control group, the expression of cleaved caspase3 decreased and the Bcl2/Bax2 ratio increased in the CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers + NIR treatment group. Cleaved caspase3 served as the marker of mitochondria-mediated apoptosis, and the Bcl2/Bax2 ratio is the classic mediator of anti-apoptosis;32 both indicated that the apoptosis pathway

Both the PI3K/AKT signaling pathway and ERK signaling pathway play an important role in regulating proliferation and apoptosis of cancer cells.33–35 Therefore, the phosphorylation levels of PI3K, AKT and ERK were studied. As shown in Fig. 5b, the phosphorylation level of PI3K was clearly inhibited and the phosphorylation levels of AKT and ERK increased in the CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers + NIR treatment group compared with the phosphorylation level displayed by the control group. Consistently, the findings indicated that the prevalent anti-apoptosis cell signaling pathways of PI3K/AKT and ERK were activated. Therefore, after treating with CuS– MnS2 nano-flowers + NIR, the anti-apoptosis cell signaling pathways were activated unexpectedly.
Apoptosis might not be the main pathway for cell death in CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers + NIR, and necroptosis is an alternative mode of regulated cell death mimicking features of apoptosis and necrosis. Necroptosis is induced by a toll-like receptor, viral or chemical exposure, radiation, and some other mediators.36 We hypothesized that necroptosis may be the vital pathway of CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers + NIR leading to cell death. Therefore, the phosphorylation level of necroptosisassociated protein MLKL was studied. Interestingly, the phosphorylation level of MLKL clearly increased in the CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers + NIR treatment group compared with that of the control group (Fig. 5c). The schematics of the mechanism of CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers + NIR treatment leading to cell death are shown in Fig. 5d. Together, the results suggested that necroptosis might be the primary pathway of CuS–MnS2 nanoflowers + NIR leading to cell death.

sections.heading: Materials and reagents
sections.text: Copper chloride dihydrate (CuCl2·2H2O), manganese(II) chloride tetrahydrate (MnCl2·4H2O), thioacetamide (TAA), and sodium dodecylbenzensulphonate (SDBS) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich (USA). A LIVE/DEAD™ Cell Imaging Kit was purchased from Thermo Fisher Scientific (USA). A Cell Counting Kit-8 (CCK-8) was obtained from Dojindo Molecular Technologies (Japan). The culture media and certified fetal bovine serum (FBS) were purchased from Gibco-BRL (USA). Cleaved-caspase3, Bcl2, Bax, p-PIK, PI3K, p-AKT, AKT, p-ERK, ERK, MLKL, p-MLKL, β-Actin, and α-Tubulin antibodies were obtained from Cell Signaling Technology (USA).

sections.heading: Synthesis of CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers
sections.text: A mixture of CuCl2·2H2O (2 mmol), MnCl2·4H2O (0.4 mmol) and SDBS (0.072 mmol) was dissolved in H2O (100 mL) by stirring for 0.5 h. The TAA solution (6 mmol, 50 mL) was then quickly added to this solution under magnetic stirring and incubated at 100 °C for 4 h. The solution was cooled to room temperature naturally. The precipitate was rinsed with water and ethanol at least three times, followed by vacuum drying at 50 °C for 4 h. The powders were stored at lab atmosphere for further characterization and application.

sections.heading: Characterization
sections.text: The crystallography structure of CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers was observed with an X-ray diffractometer (Bruker D8 Advance, Germany) equipped with Cu kα radiation (k = 0.15406 nm). A TEM and high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) (JEM 2100F, Japan) operated at 200 kV, were employed to determine the morphology and size of the nanoflowers. A SHIMADZU UV-2600 spectrophotometer was used to detect the UV–vis–NIR absorbance spectrum. A fluorescence spectroscopy (SHIMADZU RF-6000) was used to analyze extracellular ROS. MRI was performed on a clinically-used 3.0 T MR imaging instrument. Infrared thermal imaging was performed with an IR thermal camera (FLIR E50, USA). SEM (JEOL JSM-7500F) was used to investigate the morphologies of the samples at an accelerating voltage of 2 kV.

sections.heading: MRI measurements
sections.text: In vitro and in vivo MRI was performed on a clinically-used 3.0 T MRI instrument. In vitro T1-weighted MRI images were measured using a series of CuS–MnS2 nano-flower solutions in 1% agarose (0, 0.125, 0.25, 0.5, and 1 mg mL−1), and the slope was calculated by fitting the curve of an average T1-weighted MRI signal intensity versus the concentration of CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers. For in vivo imaging, female NDG mice were purchased from the Animal Laboratory of Biocytogen (Beijing, China). All animal experimental procedures were performed in accordance with the standard protocol approved by the Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee of Southern Medical University (Guangzhou, China). All the animals in this work received humane care in compliance with the Institution’s guidelines for the maintenance and use of laboratory animals in research. 5 × 106 A2780 cells resuspended in 150 μL PBS with 50% matrigel were subcutaneously injected into both lateral flanks. And the mouse was anesthetized with isoflurane throughout the experiment, and scanned with 3.0 T MRI instrument before and after CuS–MnS2 nano-flower (5 mg kg−1) were administered by intratumorally administered.

sections.heading: Cytotoxicity of the CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers
sections.text: Human ovarian carcinoma A2780 cell line, human non-small cell lung cancer H460 cell line, and human lung adenocarcinoma A549 cell line were purchased from ATCC, and human hepatocyte LO2 and MIHA cell lines were purchased from Cell Resource Center, Chinese Academy of Science. Cells (1 × 104 cells per well) were seeded into 96-well plates in standard cell media (Dulbecco’s modified Eagle’s medium containing 10% fetal bovine serum, 1% penicillin–streptomycin, and 0.1% 2-mercaptoethanol) at 37 °C in a 5% CO2 atmosphere, and then incubated with CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers at different concentrations (0, 0.05, 0.1, 0.2, 25, 0.5, and 1 mg mL−1) for 24 h. The relative cell viabilities were determined by the standard CCK-8 kit.

sections.text:

sections.heading: Photothermal performance
sections.text:
A series of 1 mL CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers solutions with concentrations of 0, 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, and 2 mg mL−1 were irradiated with an 808 nm laser (Shanghai Xilong Optoelectronics Technology Co. Ltd, China), and their temperatures were recorded with an infrared thermal imaging camera. In addition, 1 mL CuS–MnS2 nano-flower solutions with concentrations of 1 mg mL−1 were recorded at different power densities (0.4, 0.6, 0.8, 1, 2 W cm−2) for 600 s. The photostability of CuS–MnS2 nano-flower solutions was evaluated by irradiating a 1 mg mL−1 solution in a quartz cuvette with an 808 nm laser (1 W cm−2) for 10 min (laser on) and then cooling to room temperature without irradiation (laser off ). Such heating/ cooling processes were repeated four times. To obtain the photothermal conversion efficiency (η) of CuS–MnS2 nanoflower solutions, a 1 mg mL−1 solution was continuously irradiated with an 808 nm laser (1 W cm−2) for 10 min, followed by natural cooling to room temperature. The photothermal conversion efficiency (η) was calculated.23
In vitro fluorescence-visual phototherapy
Briefly, A2780 cells were pre-cultured in 96-well culture plates for 12 h, and then 100 µL of different final concentrations (0, 0.05, 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, and 1 mg mL−1) of CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers were added. Cells were exposed to an 808 nm laser at 1 W cm−2 for 3 min before being stained using the LIVE/DEAD™ Cell Imaging Kit and imaged with a fluorescent microscope (OLYMPUS IX71, Japan) to identify the live cells (green color) and dead cells (red color).

sections.heading: Detection of intracellular ROS
sections.text:
A2780 cells were pre-cultured in 96-well culture plates for 12 h, and divided into four groups: control group, NIR laser only group, CuS–MnS2 nano-flower group, and CuS–MnS2 nanoflowers + NIR group. The cells were exposed to an 808 nm laser at 1 W cm−2 for 15 min and the temperature was well controlled (42–45 °C) using the IR thermal camera. Finally, all cells were incubated with DCFH-DA (10 μmol L−1) for 2 h and observed by a fluorescent microscope (OLYMPUS IX71, Japan).
Detection of therapeutic efficacy in vivo
Five-week-old female NDG mice were purchased from the Animal Laboratory of Biocytogen (Beijing, China). 5 × 106 A2780 cells resuspended in 150 μL PBS with 50% matrigel were subcutaneously injected into the flanks of mice. When the tumors reached 100 mm3 in size, the experiment was performed. All animal experiments were performed with approval and protocols of the Southern Medical University Animal Studies Committee. A2780 tumor-bearing NDG mice were ran-
domly divided into four groups: PBS group, PBS + NIR group, CuS–MnS2 nano-flower group, and CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers + NIR group. 50 μL of a 2 mg mL−1 CuS–MnS2 nano-flower solution or PBS were intratumorally administered into the tumor region of the mice. The laser treatment groups were then irradiated under the 808 nm laser at 1 W cm−2 for 10 min. During irradiation, the real-time tumor temperature and thermal images were monitored by an infrared thermal imaging camera. To examine the pathological changes of the tumors, one tumor-bearing mouse from each group was sacrificed 1 d after treatment, and the tumors were dissected and stained with H&E.

sections.heading: Western blotting analysis
sections.text: Western blotting was used to detect the protein expression in different groups. Cells were lysed with RIPA lysis buffer containing a 1% Protease/Phosphatase Inhibitor Cocktail (CST, USA). After sonication, cell lysates were electrophoresed through an SDS polyacrylamide gel and subjected to immunoblot analysis. The following antibodies were used: cleavedcaspase3, Bcl2, Bax, p-PIK, PI3K, p-AKT, AKT, p-ERK, ERK, MLKL, pMLKL, β-Actin, and α-Tubulin (CST, USA).

sections.heading: Statistical analysis
sections.text: Quantitative data were expressed as mean ± standard deviation (SD). The statistical differences were assessed using one-way ANOVA analysis. All tests were analyzed using statistical software (SPSS version 19.0), where *p < 0.05, **p < 0.01, ***p < 0.001 were considered statistically significant.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text: Taken together, we successfully synthesized the CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers by a hydrothermal process and subsequent calcination treatment. Their usage in biomedical applications was explored along with their anticancer mechanism. The CuS– MnS2 nano-flowers exhibited superior features including broad NIR absorbance, high photothermal conversion efficiency, excellent colloidal stability, biocompatibility and multifunctional groups. These excellent multifunctionalities suggest their promise as nanotheranostic agents for MRI and PDT/PTT therapy for cancer. Furthermore, their excellent theranostic capability further highlights their potential of the CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers in precise diagnosis and treatment of cancer. The present findings indicate that necroptosis might be the main anticancer mechanism of CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers + NIR, thereby contributing to our further understanding of phototherapy.

metadata.abstractText: With a high incidence and high mortality rate, ovarian cancer presents a challenge for clinical practice. It is thus extremely urgent to investigate new diagnosis and therapy methods for the treatment of ovarian cancer. Ternary copper-based chalcogenide nanomaterials are attractive owing to their near infrared (NIR) response for cancer theranostic fields. However, improving the theranostic efficiency of these nanomaterials is challenging. Herein, CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers were easily synthesized and under NIR irradiation exhibited a relatively high photothermal conversion efficiency of 67.5% and a simultaneous reactive oxygen species (ROS) generation effect. Owing to these outstanding photothermal/photodynamic effects, excellent tumor ablation results could be achieved by the combined use of CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers and 808 nm NIR laser treatments. The main anticancer mechanism of CuS–MnS2 nanoflowers + NIR was likely necroptosis. In addition, the nano-flowers showed remarkable contrast enhancement according to magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). These CuS–MnS2 nano-flowers could thus serve as a promising multifunctional nanotheranostic agent for MRI and as a photothermal/photodynamic cancer therapy agent through necroptosis.
